commit_message:
Store old_flavor already on source host during resize

During resize, on the source host, in resize_instance(), the instance.host
and .node is updated to point to the destination host. This indicates to
the source host's resource tracker that the allocation of this instance
does not need to be tracked as an instance but as an outbound migration
instead. However for the source host's resource tracker to do that it,
needs to use the instance.old_flavor. Unfortunately the
instance.old_flavor is only set during finish_resize() on the
destination host. (resize_instance cast to the finish_resize). So it is
possible that a running resize_instance() set the instance.host to point
to the destination and then before the finish_resize could set the
old_flavor an update_available_resources periodic runs on the source
host. This causes that the allocation of this instance is not tracked as
an instance as the instance.host point to the destination but it is not
tracked as a migration either as the instance.old_flavor is not yet set.
So the allocation on the source host is simply dropped by the periodic
job.

When such migration is confirmed the confirm_resize() tries to drop
the same resource allocation again but fails as the pinned CPUs of the
instance already freed.

When such migration is reverted instead, then revert succeeds but the
source host resource allocation will not contain the resource allocation
of the instance until the next update_available_resources periodic runs
and corrects it.

This does not affect resources tracked exclusively in placement (e.g.
VCPU, MEMORY_MB, DISK_GB) but it does affect NUMA related resource that
are still tracked in the resource tracker (e.g. huge pages, pinned
CPUs).

This patch moves the instance.old_flavor setting to the source node to
the same transaction that sets the instance.host to point to the
destination host. Hence solving the race condition.

Change-Id: Ic0d6c59147abe5e094e8f13e0d3523b178daeba9
Closes-Bug: #1944759
(cherry picked from commit b841e553214be9a732703e2dfed6c97698ef9b71)
(cherry picked from commit d4edcd62bae44c01885268a6cf7b7fae92617060)
(cherry picked from commit c8b04d183f560a616a79577c4d4ae9465d03e541)
(cherry picked from commit 34e0c0205b1053d3bbe064177740aba654997fe0)
(cherry picked from commit daf4d622e87b2d76764faedac5b4885bf810ea68)

added_lines: # we have 2 cpus pinned on both computes. The source should have it # due to the outbound migration and the destination due to the # instance running there self._assert_pinned_cpus(src_host, 2) self.api.post_server_action(server['id'], post) self._wait_for_state_change(server, 'ACTIVE') # the resource allocation reflects that the VM is running on the dest # node # and running periodics does not break it either # After the revert the source host should have 2 cpus pinned due to # the instance. self._assert_pinned_cpus(src_host, 2) # running the periodic job will not break it either
deleted_lines: # This is a resource accounting bug, we should have 2 cpus pinned on # both computes. The source should have it due to the outbound # migration and the destination due to the instance running there self._assert_pinned_cpus(src_host, 0) # FIXME(gibi): This is bug 1944759 where during resize, on the source # node the resize_instance() call at the point of calling finish_resize # overlaps with a update_available_resources() periodic job. This # causes that the periodic job will not track the migration nor the # instance and therefore freeing the resource allocation. Then when # later the resize is confirmed the confirm_resize on the source # compute also wants to free up the resources, the pinned CPUs, and it # fails as they are already freed. exc = self.assertRaises( client.OpenStackApiException, self.api.post_server_action, server['id'], post ) self.assertEqual(500, exc.response.status_code) self.assertIn('CPUUnpinningInvalid', str(exc)) # confirm failed above but the resource allocation reflects that the # VM is running on the dest node # and such allocation situation is stable so as a recovery the VM # can be reset-state to ACTIVE without problem. # This is a resource accounting bug. After the revert the source host # should have 2 cpus pinned due to the instance. self._assert_pinned_cpus(src_host, 0) # running the periodic job will fix the resource accounting # this is now correct

commit_message:
Add mistral-extra in the mistral venv

Mistral has split the openstack action from the main repo, this patch
install the extra actions into the venv so we can have openstack-action
in it.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/849574
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-rabbitmq_server/+/850233
Change-Id: I03aaecd4286535ae80aca249778ea9b209b87129

commit_message:
CI: disable some jobs which are not working on older branches

Disables the multinode job because of a high failure risk,
and disabling the Ansible driver in the standalone driver as
it is no longer able to be run because it requires a version of
jinja2 which is not available.

Change-Id: I43a0fdab2efd981fba904f97980fb665bc802cb4

commit_message:
Replace deprecated ugettext_lazy and ungettext_lazy

The ugettext_lazy method and the ungettext_lazy method are both
deprecated since Django 3.0[1].

These were already replaced in Horizon repo by [2].

[1] https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.0/releases/3.0/#id3
[2] cd7c1b5110fe1f64cd9dfbeb1072b37912d0efee

Change-Id: If17fba432f4a00979f70b535bc1f1750d8a15f19

commit_message:
Fix share server listing with network subnet id

Share server list operation is supposed to accept share
network subnet ids as parameters for filtering share servers.
The share specified share network subnet ids were being
ignored. This change fixes this behavior by allowing that
search to occur properly.

Closes-Bug: #1959329

Change-Id: I6453e9d20a0b4ace0d71c501c5a65c6736554f0d

commit_message:
Validate matching double quotes in TXT recordsets.

Currently, designate does not validate that if a TXT recordset starts
with a double quote, it also ends with a double quote. So, if user has
provided TXT record in this unmatched doublequote format, zone ends up
in error.

This change verifies that if a TXT record starts with a double quote,
it also ends with a double quote.

Closes-Bug: 1980757
Change-Id: I75bd7c1657a9178c8e7ef2d66fa7318255c67582
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/41/849541/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import re @staticmethod def _paired_quotes(value): stripped_str = re.sub('[^"]', "", value) return len(stripped_str) % 2 == 0 if not self._paired_quotes(value): err = ("TXT record should have a matching number of " "double quotes.") raise InvalidObject(err)

Update port info

Make it compatible with new openstack sdk 1.0.0

added_lines: --- - name: List all ports openstack.cloud.port_info: cloud: "{{ cloud }}" register: result - name: Show output debug: msg: "{{ result.openstack_ports }}"

commit_message:
Forbid create ndp proxy on same router with same ip address

Create multiple ndp proxies with same ip address within one router
is invalid. The related database constraint was missed in previous
patchsets. The patch add some codes fixed this error.

Additionally, Fixed two typo errors.

Related-Bug: #1877301
Change-Id: Iab24ad78a3d4d9b0ee584cf0986328c9ae2bd16a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/10/841810/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if np.NDPProxy.get_objects( context, **{'router_id': ndp_proxy['router_id'], 'ip_address': ndp_proxy['ip_address']}): raise exc.NDPProxyDuplicated( router_id=ndp_proxy['router_id'], port_id=ndp_proxy['port_id'], ip_address=ndp_proxy['ip_address'])

subject: single pass instance info fetch in host manager
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-12-07 18:57:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/e1e9d7a4ce0437768f66cdf0509f7a80012472e4', 'message': "single pass instance info fetch in host manager

For deployments where CONF.filter_scheduler.track_instance_changes is
False (in order to reduce the chattiness on the message queue when there
are thousands of compute nodes sending notifications about instance
changes), performance of the HostManager's _get_host_states() method can
be negatively impacted.

HostManager._get_host_states() fetches information about each
placement-selected compute host's instances and aggregates. This
information is passed to remaining filters and weighers to use.

When CONF.filter_scheduler.track_instance_changes is False, two separate
database call was being made to get the list of instance UUIDs
associated with each host in the set of selected desinations: one to get
the HostMapping information for the host (in order to grab cell
connection information) and another call to the cell database to
retrieve the instance UUIDs for that host.

So, assuming 10 compute nodes were in the selected destination hosts
returned from the placement service, a total of 20 queries were made to
retrieve information.

With this patch, when CONF.filter_scheduler.track_instance_changes is
False, we now do a single query per target cell to retrieve all instance
UUIDs associated with all the hosts included in the selected
destinations. This essentially changes the algorithm's performance from
O(N) to O(1).

WORK IN PROGRESS:

TODO: Write unit and functional tests.

I've run all functional tests after changing the default value of
CONF.filter_scheduler.track_instance_changes to False and get no
failures. Hoping to get some initial early feedback from CERN folks
whether they are able to increase CONF.max_placement_results to 100 or
more with this patch and see better performance from their scheduler...

Change-Id: If1c2794b8926aad4b44ab8c63fb5646c913a522c

commit_message:
single pass instance info fetch in host manager

For deployments where CONF.filter_scheduler.track_instance_changes is
False (in order to reduce the chattiness on the message queue when there
are thousands of compute nodes sending notifications about instance
changes), performance of the HostManager's _get_host_states() method can
be negatively impacted.

HostManager._get_host_states() fetches information about each
placement-selected compute host's instances and aggregates. This
information is passed to remaining filters and weighers to use.

When CONF.filter_scheduler.track_instance_changes is False, two separate
database calls were being made to get the list of instance UUIDs
associated with each host in the set of selected desinations: one to get
the HostMapping information for the host (in order to grab cell
connection information) and another call to the cell database to
retrieve the instance UUIDs for that host.

So, assuming 10 compute nodes were in the selected destination hosts
returned from the placement service, a total of 20 queries were made to
retrieve information.

With this patch, when CONF.filter_scheduler.track_instance_changes is
False, we now do a single query per target cell to retrieve all instance
UUIDs associated with all the hosts included in the selected
destinations. This essentially changes the algorithm's performance from
O(N) to O(1).

The mail loop of _get_host_states is simplified to yield instead of
return. This is done because we know that we only need one HostSate
per compute. It allows us to remove some extraneous key checking.

Change-Id: If1c2794b8926aad4b44ab8c63fb5646c913a522c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/58/623558/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @staticmethod def _filter_enabled_cell_computes(cell_computes, services): """Returns a dict, keyed by cell UUID, of the ComputeNode objects that are in that cell and are managed by an enabled nova-compute service. :param cell_computes: dict, keyed by cell UUID, of a list of ComputeNode objects in that cell :param services: dict, keyed by Service.host, of Service objects enabled_cell_computes = {} for cell_uuid, computes in cell_computes.items(): enabled_computes = [] "No compute service record found for host %(host)s. " "Removing host from scheduling consideration.", enabled_computes.append(compute) if not enabled_computes: LOG.warning("After removing disabled compute services, " "cell %(cell_uuid)s ended up with no enabled " "compute hosts. Removing this cell from " "scheduling consideration.", {'cell_uuid': cell_uuid}) continue enabled_cell_computes[cell_uuid] = enabled_computes return enabled_cell_computes def _get_host_states(self, context, cell_computes, services): """Returns a generator over HostStates given a list of computes. Also updates the HostStates internal mapping for the HostManager. :param context: RequestContext for the calling user :param cell_computes: dict, keyed by cell UUID, of a list of ComputeNode objects in that cell :param services: dict, keyed by ComputeNode.host attribute, of Service objects representing the nova-compute service worker managing that compute node """ # Get resource usage across the available compute nodes: host_state_map = {} seen_nodes = set() # First filter out any compute nodes managed by disabled services enabled_cell_computes = self._filter_enabled_cell_computes( cell_computes, services) if self.track_instance_changes: instance_infos = self._instance_info else: # NOTE(jaypipes): In order to reduce the number of queries we issue # to get instance information, we grab all that information for all # relevant compute nodes in a single pass and then update each # HostState object with that collected information. This allows us # to avoid doing repeated calls to HostMapping.get_by_host() and # InstanceList.get_uuids_by_host(). instance_infos = self._get_instance_infos_for_hosts( context, enabled_cell_computes) for cell_uuid, computes in enabled_cell_computes.items(): for compute in computes: service = services.get(compute.host) seen_nodes.add(state_key) self._get_instance_info( context, compute, instance_infos)) def _get_instance_infos_for_hosts(self, context, cell_computes): """Returns a dict, keyed by ComputeNode.host, of a dict containing two keys: "updated" which is always True, and "instances" which is a dict, keyed by instance UUID, of Instance objects associated with that nova-compute service (which is the ComputeNode.host value). This is the structure that self._instance_info dict follows, unfortunately, which we need to match in order for the _get_instance_info() method to work properly. :param context: RequestContext for the calling user :param cell_computes: dict, keyed by cell UUID, of a list of ComputeNode objects in that cell """ # A dict, keyed by hypervisor hostname, of a dict, keyed by instance # UUID, of Instance objects associated with that compute node. This # dict is built up as we grab instance UUIDs for the hosts in each cell instance_infos = {} # NOTE(jaypipes): I suppose instead of doing a # CellMapping.get_by_uuid() for each cell, we could either do a # CellMappingList.get_all() *or* add a new # CellMappingList.get_all_by_uuids() method. However, for the vast # majority of cases, we're not going to be asking for >1 cell here, so # for now, just go the simple route. cell_mappings = {} for cell_uuid, computes in cell_computes.items(): try: cell_mapping = objects.CellMapping.get_by_uuid( context, cell_uuid) cell_mappings[cell_uuid] = cell_mapping except exception.CellMappingNotFound: LOG.warning('Cell mapping not found for cell %s. Not fetching ' 'instance infos for this cell.', cell_uuid) continue for cell_uuid, cell_mappping in cell_mappings.items(): computes = cell_computes[cell_uuid] with context_module.target_cell(context, cell_mapping) as cctxt: # NOTE(jaypipes): Note that we look up instance UUIDs # associated with the ComputeNode.host, which is the # nova-compute service host, not the # ComputeNode.hypervisor_hostname value, which is the actual # compute node's hostname. If we ever need this function to # operate on target compute nodes in an Ironic deployment (and # not nova-compute service hosts), we will need to change the # InstanceList.get_uuids_by_hosts() method to operate against # the hypervisor_hostname, not the Instance.host value, which # refers to the Service.host. Yeah, it's silly and confusing... host_names = [cn.host for cn in computes] uuids_by_host = objects.InstanceList.get_uuids_by_hosts( cctxt, host_names) for host_name, uuids in uuids_by_host.items(): instance_infos[host_name] = { "updated": True, "instances": { # Putting the context in the otherwise fake # Instance object at least allows out of tree # filters to lazy-load fields. uuid: objects.Instance(cctxt, uuid=uuid) for uuid in uuids }, } return instance_infos def _get_instance_info(self, context, compute, instance_infos): host_info = instance_infos.get(host_name)
deleted_lines: def _get_host_states(self, context, compute_nodes, services): """Returns a generator over HostStates given a list of computes. Also updates the HostStates internal mapping for the HostManager. # Get resource usage across the available compute nodes: host_state_map = {} seen_nodes = set() for cell_uuid, computes in compute_nodes.items(): "No compute service record found for host %(host)s", # We force to update the aggregates info each time a # new request comes in, because some changes on the # aggregates could have been happening after setting # this field for the first time self._get_instance_info(context, compute)) seen_nodes.add(state_key) def _get_instance_info(self, context, compute): host_info = self._instance_info.get(host_name)

subject: Align ironic driver secure boot with other drivers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-06-01 05:35:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/ed6e65a0cfc1117a48f9a9ac4e81c6a261b63746', 'message': "Align ironic driver with libvirt secure boot enable

Currently, flavor extra_specs are passed directly through to the
ironic node capabilities, so secure boot is enabled by setting
extra_specs secure_boot=true.

This means that there is a divergence in the interfaces between
libvirt and ironic drivers for how to enable secure boot via flavor
extra-specs. Also this means there is no way to enable secure boot via
image properties as there is for the libvirt driver.

This change adds the flavor os:secure_boot and image property
os_secure_boot as a way to enable secure boot in addition to the
existing flavor extra-specs direct approach.

Values 'required' and 'optional' are both mapped to secure_boot=true,
which is just a signalling of intent anyway, since not all hardware
(or node management drivers) support setting secure boot via API.

Change-Id: Ia8398b4590ef06bce4bb15860da4b4b9044c5be4
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2022-06-10 04:53:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/642145cf390d857909ce89894a84741190931220', 'message': "Align ironic driver with libvirt secure boot enable

commit_message:
Align ironic driver secure boot with other drivers

Currently, flavor extra_specs capabilities namespace are passed
directly through to the ironic node capabilities, so secure boot is
enabled by setting extra_specs capabilities:secure_boot=true.

This means that there is a divergence in the interfaces between the
ironic driver and libvirt/hyperv for how to enable secure boot via
flavor extra-specs. Also this means there is no way to enable secure
boot via image properties.

This change adds the flavor os:secure_boot and image property
os_secure_boot as a way to enable secure boot in addition to the
existing flavor extra-specs capabilities approach.

Values 'required' and 'optional' are both mapped to secure_boot=true,
which is just a signalling of intent anyway, since not all hardware
(or node management drivers) support setting secure boot via API.

Change-Id: Ia8398b4590ef06bce4bb15860da4b4b9044c5be4
Blueprint: secure-boot-ironic
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/43/844243/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.objects import fields from nova.virt import hardware os_secure_boot = hardware.get_secure_boot_constraint( flavor, image_meta) if os_secure_boot in (fields.SecureBoot.REQUIRED, fields.SecureBoot.OPTIONAL): capabilities['secure_boot'] = 'true'

commit_message:
Fix versions for new microversion

Fix versions endpoint to match what is expected in the microversion spec.
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/microversion_specification.html

We will return what we previously returned for < 1.1

Change-Id: I7db1fa9f1fccb3638911f0c90ad0718e1c53334d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/12/840712/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def mock_pecan_request(test_instance, host=None, version='1.0'): mock_req.environ['key-manager.microversion'] = version

commit_message:
Update the charmcraft.yaml for xena (no 22.04 base)

- Build on 20.04 amd64
- Run on 20.04 amd64, s390x, ppc64el, arm64
- Make focal-xena voting

commit_message:
Allow to provide custom configuration for VPNaaS

As we need to monitor vpn connection detailes, the only way to config vpnaas to log states and connections of vpn
is to provide own templates for VPNaaS configuration. With that we enable deployers to provide custom configuration
files for using with any vpn drivers (stronswan/openswan).

Co-Authored-By: Dmitriy Rabotyagov <noonedeadpunk@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I54dbd5c9690281af475312a277eab534403edf92
(cherry picked from commit 26b768ea5bcbe90c10e6ff8f47a64e0559fbd34d)

commit_message:
Fix the trailing-slash issue on for product-streams endpoint

ceph-radosgw is now more strict and can't handle non-canonical
paths in http requests; this patch stopes that happening, and ensures
that the endpoint is set without a trailing slash.

Change-Id: I1c2de2aad2f7652906d91865e5e214b403d2a37b
(cherry picked from commit 91e4aea4511b5d6afa21d18a84ef486097d4f542)

commit_message:
Remove the note of training-labs

Training-labs had been officially retired as no maintainer.
The information of training-labs has been deleting in the openstack
documentatioan. It is not appropriate to continue the presentation in
note form here.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-October/025586.html
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/training-labs/commit/e78d74f10558ab3e6a9a6fd7d45e617c15e9c3d8

Change-Id: I0ac3d05389041ac58fe2347171541ffaaf151fdf

commit_message:
Add a check for virtual_size at API layer

When creating a bootable volume from image, we check if the volume
can fit the image which includes several checks like size, min_disk,
virtual_size etc of image should be <= volume size.
We do check the virtual_size but however that check comes at a very
later stage in the cinder-volume process which makes the check
asynchronous.
In a case where nova requests cinder to create a bootable volume
from image, it gets an OK status from cinder-api and then fails
later at the cinder-volume layer but nova isn't aware about the
failure and times out waiting for a reply from cinder.
To avoid the above scenario, we are adding a virtual_size check at
the API layer to fail fast if the volume size doesn't satisfy the
contraints to store the image.

Closes-Bug: #1980268

Change-Id: Ia5950c2dc6186b721c9c9cfc4629d72e3b731889
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/35/847335/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinder.image import image_utils # Add a check if virtual size is greater than the volume # size, we fail early at the API layer image_meta = self.image_service.show(context, image_id) virtual_size = image_meta.get('virtual_size') if virtual_size: image_utils.check_virtual_size(virtual_size, size, image_id)

Corrected the config file to use when stopping neutron-openvswitch-agent

The use of file ml12_conf.ini has been deprecated, replaced by /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/openvswitch_agent.ini.

commit_message:
Don't use private API to get query criteria

Another change for SQLAlchemy 1.4 is the mechanics
of how the ``QueryContext`` object works.   Update the
update_match extension such that it does not rely upon the
``QueryContext`` object and uses public APIs instead.

Change-Id: I27e20e59bce8c98b5a507c617364652aa6eb33f5
(cherry picked from commit f2a94b6f1a8d1c2274ff81ae9968d22a22fd8503)

commit_message:
Tests: fix requirements for unit tests

Add WebTest to test-requirements and functional requirements which used
to be imported as a transitive requirement via pecan, but the latest
release of pecan dropped this dependency. So make this requirement
explicit.

Related-Bug: #1982110
Change-Id: I3540de632490e0105c3879a24061511f93979851
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/38/850338/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # This is necessary as pecan dropped this dependency # see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/848706 WebTest>=2.0.27 # MIT

commit_message:
Ensure english locale when running the command for ovs checks.

We parse the output of commands to get information around the
OpenVswitch versions. At least one of those commands supports
localization[1]. In order to ensure that the parsing won't fail on
unexpected character, we have to make sure all commands run with an
known locale.

We add a wrapper around the module.run_ansible ansible ansible command
that ensures that all commands run with C.UTF-8 locale.

We need to support string and list for that wrapper for command
because run_ansible[2] has a different interface depending on the
command being a string or a list. We use this behaviour to get access
to the shell.

[1] The dnf command.
[2] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/reference_appendices/module_utils.html

Closes-Bug: #1964155

Change-Id: I60f6efebecf24f3c3337cc02e8c61e0835de6ed0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible refs/changes/71/832671/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def run_locale_safe(module, *args, **kwargs): if isinstance(*args, str): cmd = 'env LANG=C.UTF-8' + str(*args) else: cmd = ['env', 'LANG=C.UTF-8'] + list(*args) return module.run_command(cmd, **kwargs) _, output, _ = run_locale_safe(module, cmd, check_rc=True) _, output, _ = run_locale_safe(module, cmd, check_rc=False) if len(versions) >= 1 and isinstance(versions[0], list): _, output, _ = run_locale_safe(module, cmd, check_rc=True) _, output, _ = run_locale_safe(module, cmd + pkgs_to_remove, check_rc=True) _, output, _ = run_locale_safe(module, cmd, check_rc=True) rc, out, err = run_locale_safe(module, cmd) if len(lp_ovs_coming_versions) == 0: result['msg'] += "Couldn't get the version of rhosp-openvswitch, " + \ "check dnf info -q rhosp-openvswitch on this host." result['failed'] = True elif len(ovs_current_version) == 0: result['msg'] += "Couldn't get the current version of the ovs-package, " + \ f"check rpm -qi {ovs_pkg} on this host." result['failed'] = True elif flatten_version(lp_ovs_coming_versions) \ != flatten_version(ovs_current_version): rc, _, _ = run_locale_safe(cmd, check_rc=False, use_unsafe_shell=True) run_locale_safe(module, cmd, check_rc=True) run_locale_safe(module, cmd, check_rc=True)
deleted_lines: _, output, _ = module.run_command(cmd, check_rc=True) _, output, _ = module.run_command(cmd, check_rc=False) if isinstance(versions[0], list): _, output, _ = module.run_command(cmd, check_rc=True) _, output, _ = module.run_command(cmd + pkgs_to_remove, check_rc=True) _, output, _ = module.run_command(cmd, check_rc=True) rc, out, err = module.run_command(cmd) if flatten_version(lp_ovs_coming_versions) \ != flatten_version(ovs_current_version): rc, _, _ = module.run_command(cmd, check_rc=False, use_unsafe_shell=True) module.run_command(cmd, check_rc=True) module.run_command(cmd, check_rc=True)

commit_message:
WIP: test multiattach volume works after disconnect

Ensure that when a multiattach volume is attached to
two instances on the same host, detaching it from the
second instance does not break its attachment to the
first instance.

Change-Id: I9e07848d3c06f2c37a2932f2ddfcaf4239c0eea4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-tempest-plugin refs/changes/26/850526/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @decorators.idempotent_id('13f28475-2aa4-4476-8b00-260854ba289c') def test_multiattach_works_after_detach(self): server_1 = self.create_server( key_name=self.keypair['name'], security_groups=[{'name': self.security_group['name']}]) multiattach_vol_type = self.create_volume_type( extra_specs={'multiattach': "<is> True"}) multi_attach_volume = self.create_volume( volume_type=multiattach_vol_type['id']) encrypted_volume = self.create_encrypted_volume( 'luks', volume_type='luks') simple_volume = self.create_volume() # Attach normal and encrypted volumes (These volumes are not used in # the current test but is used to emulate a real world scenario # where different types of volumes will be attached to the server) self.attach_volume(server_1, simple_volume) self.attach_volume(server_1, encrypted_volume) instance_ip = self.get_server_ip(server_1) # Attach volume to instance and find it's device name (eg: /dev/vdb) volume_device_name_inst_1, __ = ( self._attach_and_get_volume_device_name( server_1, multi_attach_volume, instance_ip, self.keypair['private_key'])) out_device = '/dev/' + volume_device_name_inst_1 # This data is written from the first server and will be used to # verify when reading data from second server device_data_inst_1 = self.write_data_to_device( instance_ip, out_device, private_key=self.keypair['private_key'], server=server_1, sha_sum=True) # Create another instance server_2 = self.create_server( key_name=self.keypair['name'], security_groups=[{'name': self.security_group['name']}]) instance_2_ip = self.get_server_ip(server_2) # Attach volume to instance and find it's device name (eg: /dev/vdc) volume_device_name_inst_2, __ = ( self._attach_and_get_volume_device_name( server_2, multi_attach_volume, instance_2_ip, self.keypair['private_key'])) in_device = '/dev/' + volume_device_name_inst_2 # Read data from volume device device_data_inst_2 = self.read_data_from_device( instance_2_ip, in_device, private_key=self.keypair['private_key'], server=server_2, sha_sum=True) self._verify_attachment(multi_attach_volume['id'], server_1['id']) self._verify_attachment(multi_attach_volume['id'], server_2['id']) #self.assertEqual(device_data_inst_1, device_data_inst_2) # Detach the second instance's attachment self._detach_volume(server_2, multi_attach_volume) device_data_read_inst_1 = self.read_data_from_device( instance_ip, out_device, private_key=self.keypair['private_key'], server=server_1, sha_sum=True) self.assertEqual(device_data_read_inst_1, device_data_inst_2)
